statement.text: The golden spiral is a logarithmic spiral whose growth factor is the golden ratio φ. It can be approximated by drawing quarter-circle arcs connecting opposite corners of squares in a sequence of golden rectangles. Each quarter turn outward, the spiral's radius increases by a factor of φ.
statement.formal: Polar equation: r = ae^(bθ) where b = (2/π)ln(φ) ≈ 0.306, giving growth property r(θ + π/2) = φ·r(θ)

explanation.intuition: Imagine a snail shell that grows outward in a perfect mathematical pattern. As the shell makes each complete turn, it gets exactly φ times larger. This is the golden spiral—a curve that grows at a constant rate while maintaining its shape. Unlike a circle that just repeats, or a straight spiral that spreads evenly, the golden spiral expands exponentially but smoothly.
explanation.key_insight: The golden spiral is a special case of logarithmic spiral where the growth rate is tied to φ. It's self-similar: if you zoom in or out, the spiral looks the same (scale-invariant). This property makes it mathematically elegant and explains why similar spirals appear in nature—organisms grow by adding new material in proportions that maintain structural integrity.
explanation.technical_details: In polar coordinates (r, θ), the golden spiral is r = ae^(bθ) where b = (2/π)ln(φ) ≈ 0.306. This means r(θ + π/2) = φ·r(θ)—each 90° turn increases radius by φ. The spiral has constant angle (equiangular): the tangent makes a fixed angle ψ = arctan(1/b) ≈ 73° with the radius at every point. Growth rate dr/dθ = br is proportional to distance from origin, creating exponential expansion.
common_misconceptions: All spirals in nature are golden spirals—FALSE: Most are approximations or different spirals entirely
The nautilus shell is a perfect golden spiral—FALSE: It's closer to 4:3 ratio, not φ
Spiral galaxies follow the golden spiral—OVERSIMPLIFIED: They're logarithmic but with variable parameters
The golden spiral and Fibonacci spiral are identical—CLOSE: Fibonacci spiral is an approximation

definitions_glossary.logarithmic_spiral: Spiral whose radius grows exponentially with angle
definitions_glossary.equiangular_spiral: Spiral where tangent makes constant angle with radius (same as logarithmic)
definitions_glossary.growth_factor: Ratio by which radius increases per unit angle
definitions_glossary.fibonacci_spiral: Approximation to golden spiral using quarter-circles in Fibonacci rectangles
definitions_glossary.nautilus_spiral: Spiral found in nautilus shell, roughly logarithmic but not golden
definitions_glossary.pole: Center point of the spiral (limit as r → 0)

properties: Infinite length as θ → -∞, but finite area
Growth rate proportional to distance from origin

fibonacci_approximation.method: Draw quarter-circles in successive Fibonacci rectangles
fibonacci_approximation.accuracy: Converges to true golden spiral as n → ∞
fibonacci_approximation.practical_note: Indistinguishable by eye after a few iterations

definition.@value: A logarithmic spiral with growth factor equal to the golden ratio φ

related.relationship: Plant spirals often approximate golden spiral
Galactic spirals are logarithmic (not necessarily golden)

learning_objectives: Define logarithmic spiral and golden spiral
Understand growth factor φ per quarter turn
Generate golden spiral from golden rectangles
Distinguish golden spiral from Fibonacci approximation
Recognize logarithmic spirals in nature (with caveats)
common_errors: Assuming all natural spirals are golden spirals
Confusing Fibonacci spiral with true golden spiral
Thinking the spiral reaches its center
teaching_tips: Start with construction from golden rectangles
Use real shell/plant photos but emphasize approximation
Plot in graphing software to see mathematical beauty
